text: Laurance to you what was the most
important moment in recent history and
certainly in recent history the most
amazing moment was was February 23rd
1987 you all remember that that was a
day that we observed something that
again I never would have thought we'd
seen when stars explode the brightest
fireworks in the universe is a supernova
it shines with the brightness of 10
billion stars but it turns out that all
of that light is just a small fraction
of the energy that's produced in a
supernova explosion
most of the energy comes out in
neutrinos we'd predicted that and all of
nuclear physics told us that should be
the case and in fact I even did
calculations based on it but I don't
think any of us ever thought we'd see it
but in that day in fact in some of us
have predicted how many you might see in
a detector of the type that we're
discussing here you predict if a star
exploded on the end of the galaxy 10 or
20 neutrino events February 23rd
supernova was seen and then the neutrino
experiments looked at their data and
discovered 20 neutrinos which were 19
neutrinos which was essentially almost
exactly the number that the simplest
models predicted and that again amazed
me the fact that because these are the
trio's are coming from the dense cores
of an exploding star where the densities
are unimaginably great and yet the laws
of physics as we thought we understood
them gave the right answer
